awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Effects of Developmental Hypoxia on Juvenile Cardiac Function
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project will investigate the outcome of low environmental oxygen levels (hypoxia) experienced during early development on the cardiovascular system of the American alligator, a species that naturally experiences low oxygen during embryonic life. The cardiovascular system is essential for the distribution of oxygen and metabolic fuels to active tissues. In some developing vertebrates, including humans, the function of the immature cardiovascular system can be negatively affected by environmental challenges such as low oxygen, and these changes can adversely affect the health of the adult. By contrast, species that naturally experience low oxygen during development, such as alligators, can benefit later in life from the changes to the cardiovascular system resulting from developmental hypoxia. Cardiovascular function will be assessed in two-year-old juvenile American alligators that were exposed to hypoxia as embryos, under active conditions (while exercising and after feeding). An integrative assessment will be conducted from the level of individual proteins to that of the whole animal. The broader impacts of the project include a significant number of opportunities for training students at multiple education levels in skills relevant to biomedical research, which will have a direct impact on the future work force, and training and practice in communicating science to the public. 

Developmental plasticity is a phenomenon that enables multiple environmentally mediated phenotypes to be generated from a single genotype. This plasticity, which is present in all multicellular taxa, can result in beneficial or adaptive changes that enhance function during juvenile and adult life. Hypoxia is an ecologically relevant environmental condition that, if encountered during embryonic life when organ systems are developing, can result in altered juvenile phenotypes that can impact organismal performance and affect animal fitness. Despite the important role hypoxia plays in causing phenotypic change, fundamental questions remain regarding the long-term effects of developmental hypoxia in vertebrates. This project investigates the impact of hypoxia experienced during a critical period of development on cardiovascular function of juvenile alligators at multiple levels of biological organization: from whole-animal performance, to functional studies of the cardiovascular system, to the organ, cellular, protein, and gene levels of organization. Alligators will be studied because they can naturally experience hypoxia during development and as adults. This approach will establish links between molecular and cellular traits, including changes in expression of genes involved in calcium dynamics and in cardiomyocyte contractility that underpin differences in cardiac output at the whole organism level. This multi-level approach will provide a comprehensive understanding of how embryonic hypoxia impacts cardiovascular function, with applicability to other vertebrate systems. The research findings will provide basic information that will be needed to make informed animal management decisions in the era of global climate change, and could lead to future treatment options for cardiovascular disease states. The project involves research training of graduate students and undergraduate students recruited from groups under-represented in science, as well as outreach to K-12 students and the general public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of North Dakota Main Campus

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Environmentally induced changes in morphology, physiology, and behavior are common in all forms of life. Such changes often allow organisms to cope with environmental challenges. For instance, molecular oxygen is vital for most forms of life on earth, but oxygen availability varies in different environments, physiological states, and developmental stages. The cardiovascular system of vertebrates plays an essential role in delivering oxygen to cells throughout the body and is sensitive to oxygen levels thru life. In fact, low oxygen availability (hypoxia) during embryonic life can permanently affect the developing cardiovascular system and change the way the heart and vascular system functions later in life. Despite the important role hypoxia plays in programming cardiovascular traits, fundamental questions remain regarding the long-term effects of hypoxia on the cardiovascular system in vertebrates.

Intellectual Merit: In this collaborative grant, we studied hypoxia-induced changes in cardiovascular form and function in American alligators and common snapping turtles. Studies focused on molecular, physiological, and morphological changes induced by low oxygen levels during embryogenesis and long-lasting effects that persisted in juveniles. The effect of hypoxia was investigated in functional studies of the organ system, as well as the organ, cellular, protein and gene levels of organization. This approach link changes at the molecular and cellular level to differences in cardiac output at the whole organism level. This work helps us better understand the mechanisms that vertebrates use to maintain oxygen homeostasis, which is essential for life. Studies at the University of North Dakota focused on genomes, epigenomes, and gene expression.

We sequenced, assembled, and annotated the common snapping turtle genome. This is a major community resource for all studies of the snapping turtle and particularly valuable for research on the cardiovascular system. We utilized this genome to study the effects of embryonic hypoxia on DNA methylation and gene expression in the heart of juvenile snapping turtles. We found that embryonic hypoxia programs DNA methylation and gene expression patterns and that these changes are associated with enhanced cardiac anoxia tolerance later in life. We identified several candidate genes, transcription factors, and signaling pathways that may underlie differences in heart rate and cardiomyocyte physiology. Programming of cardiac anoxia tolerance has major ecological implications for snapping turtles, because these animals regularly exploit anoxic environments throughout their lifespan. We also examined the role of chemoreceptors in mediating the effects of hypoxia on the heart of snapping turtle embryos.

Work in alligators focused on gene expression patterns in embryos and 5-year old juveniles. We are currently writing a manuscript describing our findings in embryos. In brief, we found that exposure to hypoxia significantly altered gene expression patterns in hearts of alligator embryos: 220 genes were upregulated and 181 genes downregulated by hypoxia. Another 79 genes were affected by the interaction between hypoxia and the developmental stage of embryos. Genes affected by hypoxia were enriched for genes related to protein degradation, cell motility, sodium transport, and cardiovascular physiology (e.g., apelin signaling, adrenergic signaling, cardiac muscle contraction). The interaction between oxygen treatment and embryonic stage altered expression of genes involved in oxygen transport. Gene networks were related to cardiovascular development (pathology of ductus arteriosis), physiology (adrenergic signaling in cardiomyocytes, myosin and troponin complex), and protein metabolism (the proteasome). We are in the process of analyzing gene expression patterns in juveniles and will write a paper describing our findings.

Overall, this research advances our understanding of the impact of embryonic hypoxia on cardiovascular development and physiology in alligators, turtles, and provides comparative data to help understand the evolution of cardiovascular responses in vertebrates more broadly.

Broader Impacts: We enhanced classroom learning, improved undergraduate research experiences, and trained graduate students to do research that integrates across multiple biological scales. Undergraduates in Molecular Biology Techniques (19 students) cloned genes during their class project. In addition, 2 undergraduates were involved in long-term research experiences (REUs) through extended internships that lasted 2-3 years. These students worked in the laboratory for 10 hours per week during the school year and full-time during summers from their sophomore to senior year. Long-term REUs provided students the opportunity to carry out master’s level research. One long-term REU student has entered a Ph.D. program at a prestigious university and the other is in medical school. Two individuals received post-baccalaureate training. Another 8 undergraduates participated in a traditional 10-week summer REU program. Three graduate students and 1 postdoctoral fellow were also trained during this grant. Long-term REU students and graduate students developed competence with multiple molecular biology techniques and bioinformatics methods, a thorough understanding of genetics, epigenetics, cell and developmental biology, and the ability to link these disciplines in a meaningful way. The project provided postdoctoral training in bioinformatics to a computational chemist.


Last Modified: 11/10/2023
Modified by: Turk Rhen
